qas.question: What evidence leads most scientists to accept that birds are a specialized subgroup of theropod dinosaurs?
What is a group of theropods which include dromaeosaurs and oviraptorids?
Recent discoveries in what country demonstrate many small theropod feathered dinosaurs.

context: Based on <a0_0>fossil and biological evidence<a0_0/>, most scientists accept that birds are a specialized subgroup of theropod dinosaurs, and more specifically, they are members of <a1_0>Maniraptora<a1_0/>, a group of theropods which includes dromaeosaurs and oviraptorids, among others. As scientists have discovered more theropods closely related to birds, the previously clear distinction between non-birds and birds has become blurred. Recent discoveries in the Liaoning Province of northeast <a2_0>China<a2_0/>, which demonstrate many small theropod feathered dinosaurs, contribute to this ambiguity.
